skill.author: AndresNaza

content.user_title: Plan Strategic Roadmaps with Expert Capacity Analysis
content.value_statement: Managing quarterly roadmaps and sprint capacity is complex and time-consuming. This skill provides expert guidance for breaking down epics into milestones, estimating capacity using industry-standard models, and creating collaborative planning workflows.
actual_capabilities: Guide collaborative quarterly roadmap planning with epic prioritization
Break down epics into appropriately-sized milestones using capacity models
Calculate team capacity based on developer count and sprint duration
Provide sprint planning workflows with milestone allocation strategies
Recommend sizing guidelines for small, medium, and large work items
Explain roadmap hierarchy from quarters to epics to milestones to sprints
limitations: Does not execute commands or create files automatically
Does not integrate directly with ClickUp or other project management tools
Provides planning methodology and guidance rather than automated tracking
Requires user to implement recommended file structure manually

use_cases.title: Quarterly Planning for Engineering Teams
use_cases.description: Engineering managers use this skill to plan quarterly roadmaps by breaking strategic goals into epics, estimating team capacity, and allocating milestones across six sprints with proper buffer allocation.

use_cases.title: Sprint Capacity Analysis
use_cases.description: Technical leads leverage the capacity model to estimate how many points their team can complete in a sprint, size milestones appropriately, and identify when work items need to be split.

use_cases.title: Epic Breakdown and Milestone Planning
use_cases.description: Product managers apply the planning hierarchy to decompose large initiatives into trackable milestones, ensure each milestone delivers meaningful value, and create realistic delivery timelines.

prompt_templates.title: Initialize Team Capacity Configuration
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me configure my team for roadmap planning. We have 3 developers working on 2-week sprints.
prompt_templates.scenario: First-time setup for a small engineering team

prompt_templates.title: Plan Quarterly Roadmap
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to plan Q2 2026 with three major epics: user authentication, payment integration, and mobile app. Help me break these down and estimate capacity.
prompt_templates.scenario: Quarterly planning session with multiple initiatives

prompt_templates.title: Size and Break Down Epic
prompt_templates.prompt: My epic for implementing real-time notifications seems too large. Help me break it into milestones that fit within our sprint capacity of 60 points.

prompt_templates.title: Allocate Milestones to Sprint
prompt_templates.prompt: For Sprint 5, I have 4 milestones available totaling 45 points, but my team capacity is only 40 points. Help me decide which milestones to include and what to defer.
prompt_templates.scenario: Sprint planning with over-allocation requiring prioritization

output_examples.input: What is the recommended capacity per developer in a 2-week sprint?
output_examples.output: The recommended capacity model is 20 points per developer per 2-week sprint, where 1 point equals approximately half a day of focused work. A 2-week sprint has 10 working days, and this model includes a built-in 15% buffer for unexpected work, meetings, and context switching. For example, a team of 3 developers would have 60 points of capacity per sprint.

output_examples.input: How should I size milestones within an epic?
output_examples.output: Milestones should be sized according to these guidelines: Small milestones are 5-8 points taking about 1 week, Medium milestones are 10-15 points taking 1.5-2 weeks, and Large milestones are 18-25 points taking a full sprint. Any milestone over 25 points should be split into smaller milestones. Each epic should contain 2-4 milestones that represent meaningful checkpoints, not just task lists.

output_examples.input: Explain the planning hierarchy for roadmaps.
output_examples.output: The planning hierarchy has four levels: Quarter (6 sprints of strategic planning), Epic (major feature or initiative living in one file), Milestone (meaningful checkpoint within an epic, 2-4 per epic), and Sprint (2-week execution window). For example, a quarter might contain Epic A with 3 milestones allocated to Sprints 1-3, and Epic B with 2 milestones in Sprints 2 and 4. This hierarchy keeps strategic planning separate from detailed execution tracking.

best_practices: Include a 15% capacity buffer in sprint planning to account for unexpected work and avoid over-commitment
Keep milestones between 5-25 points to ensure they are trackable yet meaningful, splitting anything larger
Use collaborative planning workflows where the AI asks questions and the user makes final decisions on priorities
anti_patterns: Do not treat milestones as detailed task lists - they should be coarse checkpoints suitable for capacity planning
Avoid allocating 100% of team capacity to planned work without buffer for interruptions and uncertainty
Do not create epics or milestones without estimating points - unestimated work cannot be planned into sprints

faq.question: How does this skill differ from project management tools like ClickUp?
faq.answer: This skill provides strategic planning methodology and capacity guidance, while tools like ClickUp handle detailed execution tracking. The skill helps you plan what to build and when, but you still need project management tools for daily task tracking, pull requests, and QA workflows.

faq.question: What is the difference between an epic and a milestone?
faq.answer: An epic is a large strategic initiative or feature that lives in one file throughout its lifecycle. A milestone is a meaningful checkpoint within an epic, with 2-4 milestones per epic. Milestones are sized for capacity planning and allocated to specific sprints.

faq.question: Can I customize the capacity model for my team?
faq.answer: Yes, the default model of 20 points per developer per 2-week sprint is a starting point. You can adjust based on your team's velocity, context switching overhead, and meeting load. The key is to include realistic buffers and track actuals over time.

faq.question: How many milestones should I plan per sprint?
faq.answer: This depends on your team capacity and milestone sizes. For a 3-developer team with 60 points capacity, you might plan 3-4 medium milestones, or 2 large milestones, or a mix. Always leave buffer capacity and avoid over-committing to exactly 60 points.

faq.question: Does this skill create files or integrate with tools automatically?
faq.answer: No, this is a guidance and methodology skill. It provides expert advice on planning structure, capacity calculations, and workflows, but you need to implement the recommended file structure and tool integrations manually or with other Claude Code capabilities.

faq.question: What does collaborative planning mean in this skill?
faq.answer: Collaborative planning means the skill asks you questions about goals, priorities, and constraints rather than making decisions automatically. For example, when planning a quarter, it asks about your strategic objectives and helps you define epics together rather than generating a plan unilaterally.
